instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H_CPU: What is PPBUS_G3H_CPU? PPBUS_G3H_CPU is the .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PLT_RST_L: What is PLT_RST_L? This is an abbreviation of ‚ÄúPLT_RESET_L‚Äù ‚Äì when you see ‚ÄúPLT_RST_L", assume the person meant to type PLT_RESET_L.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi guys.

First i wanna congratulate to everyone in this community for the progress made with the right to repair  üññ :cool: .

Now... I have this board <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which gets 20v powers on fan spins fast and no image no backlight. All diode mode measurements on all Coils are fine and also getting all necessary voltages just not getting backlight and CPU voltages. No liquid spill or corrosion anywhere the board looks like new. Any ideas would be appreciated 

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
What is start and final CPU core voltage?
Any fault history available?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: No repairs done before. I compared to a working board on L7370 pin 1 i should have 6.8v but it's 0v. Also on L7210 and L7220 no voltage i didn't have time today to check I'll see tomorrow...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Stop to check DC voltage on the input pin of the coils from buck converters.
Didn't look strange that value for you?
What is <RESISTOR>R7370</RESISTOR> voltage?

Do you get L7730 and other voltages from pages 61 & 62?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
On L7730 i get 1.06v and on <RESISTOR>R7370</RESISTOR> 0.72v sometimes it's losing it 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL> is 13v
L7930 1.8v
L7960 pin 1 0.5v and pin 2 0.9v
L8060 pin 2 it's 1v
L8030  it's 1v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I didn't write:
L8060 pin 1 0.3v
L7960 pin 1 now showing 0.9v maybe i didn't measure good first time.
L7900 pin 1 sits around 2.6v and pin 2 is 1v ü•≥

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Any reason to continue verifying DC voltage on the wrong pin of a buck converter coil???
As I said, pin 1 (input) is not for DC voltage.
If you don't believe me, use an o-scope and don't waste your time in the future.

Do you get <SIGNAL>PM_EN_CPUVCC</SIGNAL>?
If yes, try known good BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_EN_CPUVCC</SIGNAL> it's 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Now even <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0.5 and shows 20v drawn. Type C controllers issues? No short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
What happened to lose <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

Post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> basic voltages: <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.
Remove F7000 and check <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage.

Does the board turn on with known good battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi 2informaticos. 

The laptop got back the voltages probably the cable was bad. On <RESISTOR>R7148</RESISTOR> both  <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> the voltage goes up to 1.8v and goes down. The signal comes from PMIC...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: All other basic voltages are stable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Yes all else is good I double checked and also Diode mode on every coil

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7800</CHIP> requires some power good signals, to release <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is pulled-up to <SIGNAL>3V_S0</SIGNAL> through <RESISTOR>R7846</RESISTOR>, check it; should pulse higher than 1.8V.
If all these good, something happens when CPU power supply tries to start.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7846</RESISTOR> on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> i have 3v and 0v on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>. <RESISTOR>R7846</RESISTOR> is 10k as it should be. <RESISTOR>R7842</RESISTOR> is 100k and R7841is 40k instead of 100k

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Force the board to S5 state; short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground 5s.
Then trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for pulse at <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I forced the S5state and now when plugged in i get 3v on button when pressed comes back and i get 1.6v on  <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and goes back to 0v. Few times stayed longer at 1.6v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
1.6V is lower than expected, as it is pulled-up to 3V.
May have a problem with <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, or other chip connected there; SMC, or PCH.
Be sure all power good signals received by <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> are good.
Of course, do not expect <SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_CPUVCC</SIGNAL> yet.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I took out and resoldered both <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> and the SMC still the same. All contact under then are good. It boosts up to 1.9v and stays there. PCH issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Just as i wrote the last reply i said let me measure again and i got a fan spin and 3.3v all power good. Now not showing picture  :ROFLMAO:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Powers on on battery or on charger fan spins no backlight voltage and no chime...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Board turns on every time now?
Do you get USB activity, external video?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Yes turns on every time fan spins for a bit and turns off and CPU stays cold. No external and USB only the type c hub lights up but when i plug in a mouse nothing happens

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"fan spins for a bit and turns off"
So doesn't really turns on, just trying...
When fan spins, check which coils get voltage.
Did you try known good BIOS?

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> comes high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Getting back to this one :)

I have on all coils voltage besides CPU and backlight. <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> is 0v measured on <RESISTOR>R2014</RESISTOR>. Bios I haven't tried still

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I just tried a new bios but still the same...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"I have on all coils voltage besides CPU and backlight."
Steady voltage, not pulsing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: No all steady like it's powering on and staying stable.  <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>  comes from SMC right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Before L7210/20, you must get voltage at L7370 and L7730; check that.
If yes, check <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> voltage; pins 41, 42, 48.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
L7730 i have 1v and on L7370 0v. 
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>  Pin 41 13v, pin42 5v and on pin 48 0.8v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
You don't have <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
Check the power good signals of <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (1 OF 10) block.

Be aware, voltages generated by <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> don't have accessible power good signal.
So check in pages 61 & 62 if all voltages are correct.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: The client decided to replace the board. Thank you :)
